Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 5/16/2024 . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12605 A doptive family evaluation
• (1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within 90
days of the family signing an adoption
application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
Two of three adoptive family evaluations reviewed did not complete the adoptive
evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an adoption application.
FOM Policy – 722-06B Family Team Meeting: Practice Guidance
Documentation
The DHS 1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action
steps, safety concerns and the safety plan, and
any recommendation made for the family during
the FTM. The DS -1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, must be completed for every FTM.

Two of eight foster child records reviewed did not have documentation of an FTM
1105 as required.
FOM POLICY 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS – AGREEMENT AND
SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
Caseworker, Supervisor, second line supervisor,
when siblings in care are place apart, parents who
are a member of a participating household. Youth
ages 14 and older. Foster parents, relative
caregivers, and unrelated court -ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan: I have participated in the
Development of the Case service plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
Four of eight foster care records and one Independent Living record reviewed
were either missing signatures, signatures were obtained after 30 days and yes
or no were not checked on the PATP’s.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Special evaluation 2023C0000787 was initiated on 7/11/2023 regarding a licensed
foster parent having an altercation with her biological daughter. Foster parent left the
location while intoxicated with four foster children in the car placed in her care. A
traffic stop was initiated, and the foster parent was observed to have glossy eyes and
intoxicants could be smelled coming from the vehicle. It is alleged that the foster
parent was transferred to jail and blew a 0.111. The evaluation was very well written,
and revocation of the foster home license was initiated, however, still pending.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Special evaluation #2024SEC0001383 was initiated on 2/27/2024 regarding the
foster child refusing to take her medication and the foster parent hit the foster child
on her face and told the foster child that she hated her. The foster child had a red
mark on her face. The evaluation was thorough and well written. The foster parent
was using corporal punishment as discipline. The license foster parents were found
in violation of licensing rules and agency policy. Revocation of the foster home
license was initiated, however, still pending.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the individual CAP is as follows.
The one CAP submitted was in response to the interim inspection completed on
8/21/23 and the CAP was approved on 8/23/2023. The agency was cited for one
violation, 722-08D – PATP Signatures. There was a decrease from 16 of 20
PATP’s in 2023 to 4 of 8 PATP’s in 2024. The agency will need to complete
additional planning/training to reduce the repeated violation for PATP’s and ensure
compliance with this violation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA) was reviewed and discussed onsite
on 5/2/2024. The chief administrator indicated the foster care staff have made
improvements with their last interim CAP. She stated the foster care supervisors
are discussing the interim CAP during supervision and the foster care staff are
double checking for missed signatures during their quarterly reports utilizing the
MiSACWIS checklist. She stated that needed signatures are discussed during
team meetings also. She stated the program manager/director maintains a list of
all PATPs and the due dates for reports and discusses them during the weekly
foster care meetings. This process seems to be helping the foster care staff to

maintain compliance. The CA said the clerical department has been assisting as
well as PATPs are not able to be uploaded without appropriate signatures
indicated on the document.
The CA stated that barriers and systemic factors that have impacted rules, ISEP,
policy and contract compliance are workers continuing to require reminders to
obtain all signatures on PATPs within the required timeframe. She said however,
there has been some improvement in this area as the supervisors and director are
reviewing the spreadsheet weekly during team meetings. The CA said the workers
are not consistently completing tasks timely per policy and ISEP. Other barriers
include the supervisory oversight through the use of monthly supervision,
MiSACWIS checklist, weekly foster care team meetings and reviewing databases
and spreadsheets. The CA said regular check-ins/emails and supervisors/program
manager have had to maintain direct foster care cases when there were staffing
issues/shortage, which led to oversight issues because the supervisor/program
manager having reduced time to focus on supervisory tasks with the new workers.
Financial Overview
The agency certified independent auditor’s report dated September 30, 2023, and
the agency annual financial report was reviewed. There were no financial
concerns identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed love working for the agency and feel very supported by their
coworkers and the administration. The staff interviewed reported the only thing
they would change is to hire more staff and make the caseload size smaller so
they can spend more time with the youth on their caseload. Staff feel really
appreciated and love getting the token buttons they receive from the
administration leadership. Staff reported this helps with encouraging the staff and
assist in supporting their self-worth.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The office appears to have adequate space and equipment for the staff members
to complete their required responsibilities. Physical CHRI and case files are all
stored securely, preventing unauthorized access. No concerns were noted.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
